0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency: 60 mg/kg IV infusion ONCE weekly

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in children

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to alpha-1 proteinase inhibitor products
  • IgA deficient patients with antibodies against IgA

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• IgA deficiency, selective or severe with known antibodies to IgA; increased risk of severe hypersensitivity and anaphylaxis; monitor vital signs continuously during infusion
  • risk of transmitting infectious agents (eg, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease); derived from pooled human plasma
  • report possible infections from alpha-1 proteinase inhibitor to manufacturer for Aralast(TM) or Aralast-NP(TM) at 1-800-423-2090 or for Glassia(R) at 1-866-GLASSIA or the FDA 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest discomfort (6%)
  • Hepatic:Increased liver aminotransferase level (11.1%), Increased liver enzymes (6%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (3% to 6%), Headache (0.7% to 9%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (15%), Sinusitis (6%), Upper respiratory infection (12%)
Serious
Respiratory:Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (12%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Alpha-1 proteinase inhibitor (alpha-1 PI) deficiency (also known as alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency) is characterized by reduced levels of alpha-1 PI in the blood and lungs. Patients with severe alpha-1 PI deficiency have increased levels of neutrophil and neutrophil elastase levels in lung epithelial lining fluid. Alpha-1 PI (human) therapy augments the level of the deficient protein and theoretically corrects the imbalance between neutrophil elastase and protease inhibitors, which may protect the lower respiratory tract.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Total body clearance: 0.68 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance: 862 to 940 mL/day

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • approved for IV use only
  • use within 3 hr after reconstitution; should be reconstituted at room temperature using the supplied transfer device and diluent
  • Prolastin(R): do not refrigerate after reconstitution
  • Zemaira(R) and Glassia(TM): administer using a 5-micron infusion filter
  • Aralast(TM), Aralast NP(TM) and Prolastin(R): a 20-micron filter should be used when transferring any reconstituted product into empty, intravenous containers
  • infuse at a maximum rate of 0.08 mL/kg/min for Aralast(TM), Aralast NP(TM), Zemaira(R), and Prolastin(R), or 0.04 mL/kg/min for Glassia(TM); if adverse events occur, the rate should be reduced or interrupted

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in serum alpha-1 proteinase inhibitor levels is indicative of therapeutic response
  • slowed progression of emphysema or decrease in frequency, duration, or severity of pulmonary exacerbations may indicate efficacy
  • infusion rate; during administration
  • signs of hypersensitivity and/or infusion-related reactions; during administration
  • vital signs; continuously throughout infusion

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Aralast NP
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 MG
  • Glassia
    Intravenous Solution: 1 MG
  • Prolastin-C
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 MG
  • Zemaira
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient of risk for transmission of infectious agents due to pooled human plasma product.
  • This drug may cause headaches and dizziness.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of hypersensitivity reactions.
